ğŸ“ˆ TimeSeries

BLite 1.12 introduces a native TimeSeries page type â€” a dedicated, append-only storage format optimised for high-throughput time-ordered data with automatic retention-based pruning. No background threads, no daemons: pruning is triggered transparently on insertion.

ğŸ“Œ How it works

When a collection is marked as TimeSeries, every new insert goes to a chain of TimeSeries pages instead of slotted data pages. Each page packs BSON documents sequentially and tracks the latest timestamp in its header. When the retention threshold is reached, entire expired pages are freed in a single pass â€” no per-document scanning needed.

Page Layout

OffsetSizeField
0â€“3132 BStandard PageHeader (PageType.TimeSeries = 12)
32â€“398 BLastTimestamp â€” ticks of the newest entry on this page
40â€“434 BEntryCount â€” number of BSON documents stored
44â€“474 BReserved
48+variableBSON documents packed sequentially (no slots, no gaps)

Enabling TimeSeries on a Collection

Call SetTimeSeries() on any DynamicCollection:

using var engine = new BLiteEngine("iot.db");
var sensors = engine.GetOrCreateCollection("sensors");

// Enable TimeSeries with a 7-day retention window
// The second argument names the timestamp field in each document.
// Leave it empty ("") to use insertion time automatically.
sensors.SetTimeSeries("timestamp", TimeSpan.FromDays(7));

engine.Commit();

Inserting Time-Stamped Documents

After enabling TimeSeries, use the standard Insert / InsertAsync API. BLite routes inserts to TimeSeries pages automatically. The timestamp is read from the field named in SetTimeSeries; if the field is absent or empty, the current UTC time is used.

var doc = sensors.CreateDocument(
    ["deviceId", "temperature", "timestamp"],
    b => b
        .Set("deviceId",    "sensor-42")
        .Set("temperature", 23.5)
        .Set("timestamp",   DateTime.UtcNow));

sensors.Insert(doc);
âš ï¸ Timestamp field types

The TTL field must contain either a BSON DateTime or an Int64 (ticks). Any other type is ignored and insertion time is used as fallback.

Automatic Pruning

Pruning is triggered automatically on insert when either condition is true:

  • 1 000 documents have been inserted since the last prune, or
  • 5 minutes have elapsed since the last prune.

The engine walks the page chain from the oldest end and frees every page whose LastTimestamp is older than UtcNow âˆ’ RetentionPolicy. It stops at the first non-expired page, so the scan is O(freed pages), not O(all pages).

Reading Data

All standard read methods work on TimeSeries collections:

// Full scan â€” returns all documents on all active TS pages
foreach (var d in sensors.FindAll()) { ... }

// Lookup by _id via primary B-Tree
var doc = sensors.FindById(id);

// BLQL query (filter, sort, project â€¦)
var recent = sensors.Query("""{ "deviceId": "sensor-42" }""")
    .Sort("""{ "timestamp": -1 }""")
    .Take(100)
    .ToList();

Force Prune (Testing / Admin)

To trigger pruning immediately â€” useful in tests or admin tooling â€” call ForcePrune():

sensors.ForcePrune();
engine.Commit();

In BLite Studio, the TimeSeries tab exposes a âš¡ Force Prune button alongside the configuration form.

Checking the Configuration

bool isTs = sensors.IsTimeSeries;  // true

var (retentionMs, ttlField) = sensors.GetTimeSeriesConfig();
// retentionMs = 604800000  (7 days in ms)
// ttlField    = "timestamp"

Important Caveats

âš ï¸ Converting an existing collection
  • Existing documents are NOT migrated. They stay in their original slotted pages and are never pruned by the retention policy.
  • All indexes remain valid â€” primary B-Tree and secondary indexes continue to serve both old and new documents.
  • Only documents inserted after enabling TimeSeries are written to TS pages and are subject to pruning.
  • One-way operation â€” there is no built-in way to revert to standard mode once enabled.
ğŸ“Œ v1 known limitation â€” stale B-Tree entries after pruning

When pages are freed by pruning, the primary B-Tree index retains stale entries pointing to the freed pages. FindAll() silently skips documents whose page has been freed (returning null guards are in place), so reads remain safe. A future release will clean up stale index entries during the prune pass.

BLite Studio

The TimeSeries tab in BLite Studio lets you configure and monitor any collection:

  • Status badge â€” TIME SERIES (green) or STANDARD (grey)
  • TTL field name input
  • Retention period (days) via a numeric picker
  • Save TimeSeries Configuration button
  • âš¡ Force Prune button â€” visible only when TimeSeries is already enabled
  • Sidebar TS badge â€” TimeSeries collections show a small green TS chip next to their name

Quick Reference

APIDescription
SetTimeSeries(field, retention)Enable TimeSeries mode. field can be empty to use insertion time.
IsTimeSeriesReturns true if the collection is in TimeSeries mode.
GetTimeSeriesConfig()Returns (RetentionPolicyMs, TtlFieldName).
ForcePrune()Runs the prune pass immediately, ignoring insert-count and time thresholds.
Insert(doc) / InsertAsync(doc)Standard insert â€” routed to TS pages automatically when in TS mode.
FindAll() / BLQL Query()Standard reads â€” operate transparently across TS and slotted pages.
